sub_topic: Preparation of phenylalanine from benzyl chloride and ammonia
message_1: What is the exact stoichiometric ratio of benzyl chloride and ammonia required for the preparation of 1 mole of phenylalanine, assuming complete conversion and a yield of 100%?
message_2:
The synthesis of phenylalanine from benzyl chloride and ammonia can be represented by the following balanced chemical equation:

C6H5CH2Cl + 2 NH3 â†’ C6H5CH2NH2 + NH4Cl

In this reaction, 1 mole of benzyl chloride (C6H5CH2Cl) reacts with 2 moles of ammonia (NH3) to produce 1 mole of phenylalanine (C6H5CH2NH2) and 1 mole of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl).

Therefore, the exact stoichiometric ratio of benzyl chloride to ammonia required for the preparation of 1 mole of phenylalanine is 1:2, assuming complete conversion and a yield of 100%.
